Notes:
Still lots of reoccuring text, probably not a polygraph
Noticed only 25 letters despite large chunk of ciphertext, must be a playfair.

After part 1, look for COMMA
ESXZEF most appearing 6 letter word -> most likely COM?MA
XEEF most appearing 4 letter word -> most likely OMMA

Based on digraphs before OMMA, we know the second letter of the digraph must be a 'C'. 
11 digraphs prefixing OMMA -> YM, KS, WS, CM, CS, TE, KG, WE, SE, SG, SY

From this information, we can get 1 row and 1 column (with 'C' as the junction), but no order other than the position of 3 letters (C,M,S).

Noticed that first word is 3 letters, CYWSXEEF. Based off the known letters so far, the only two acceptable words that could appear before a comma are YES or YET

Using self built generator, ran sequence with YET for 12 hours with no legible results when searching for common english words.

Changed sequence for possibility of YES, after about 2 hours results quickly showed up. This was a result of my code testing the key input (puts C in the first column/row of the key, then moves it along, just happens to be in the first column/row). This reduced a significant amount of time required. In particular the key sequence with the most THE also returned some words such as DEATHEATER -> must be Harry Potter.

Knowing this, I first rebuilt the key, inputting in the values that I know were correct for sure. Using simple cryptanalysis on words with few scrabled letters such as POINTED (from POTNTED), LIFEWITH (from LXFEWTIH), and VOLDEMORT (from NOLDEMORT). Some of the digraphs showed obvious down/right shifts which guaranteed their placement, eventually filling out the entire Playfair key.

Ran again with the new key and retreived the deciphered text.
